metadata.title: High-performance Cu/ZnO catalysts prepared using a three-channel microreactor

Fig. 1 Flow diagram of preparation process and the general structure of the three -channel microreactor. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 HRTEM images of precipitates (a) 200 nm in scale (b) 50 nm in scale (c) 20 nm in scale. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 EDS patterns of precipitates prepared at different ratios of water layer. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 DTG curves of the precipitates at different ratios of water layer. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Influence of water layer on pH changes during aging process. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 XRD patterns of precursors prepared at different ratios of water layer. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 DTG curves of the precursors prepared at different ratios of water layer. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 HRTEM images of the oxides (a) EDS mapping (b) the oxide prepared at ratio of 4/9 (c) FFT pattern of region Ⅰ (d) FFT pattern of region Ⅱ (e) FFT pattern of region Ⅲ (f) FFT pattern of region Ⅳ. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 TPR curves of oxides prepared at different ratios of water layer. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 XRD patterns of oxides prepared at different ratios of water layer together with the fitting diagram displayed as an example. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Catalytic performance of the catalysts prepared at different ratios of water layer via the comparison with the commercial catalyst in the synthesis of methanol from syngas. Fig. 11 Fig. 12 Schematic diagram of the co-precipitation process at the entrance section. Fig. 12 Fig. 13 Relation between Pearson coefficients and catalytic activities. Fig. 13 Table 1 Influence of water layer from precipitates to precursors. Table 1 Ratio Pearson Coefficient Aging time/min A/ZM Zn content/% 0 0.919 21.7 0.693 24.8 1/6 0.954 21.3 0.429 26.1 1/3 0.979 20.7 0.354 27.1 4/9 0.988 20.1 0.289 27.5 A/ZM stands for peak area ratio of 13.0° (Aurichalcite) and 17.5° (Zincian Malachite). Table 2 Characterizations of oxides prepared at different ratios of water layer. Table 2 Ratio d (CuO) nm BET m2·g−1 SACu m2·g−1 IFR Catalytic activityg MeOH· g−1 catalyst· h−1 SAcu activityg MeOH· m2 SACu · h−1 0 6.5 48.7 7.0 0.868 1.10 0.16 1/6 6.8 47.0 5.7 0.885 1.35 0.24 1/3 7.0 45.5 5.4 0.900 3.51 0.65 4/9 7.2 44.7 4.6 0.911 6.32 1.37 High-performance Cu/ZnO catalysts prepared using a three-channel microreactor Xin Jiang a ⁎ Xinchao Chen a Chen Ling a Shuaishuai Chen a Zhongbiao Wu b a Zhejiang Provincial Key Laboratory of Advanced Chemical Engineering Manufacture Technology, College of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310027, PR China Zhejiang Provincial Key Laboratory of Advanced Chemical Engineering Manufacture Technology College of Chemical and Biological Engineering Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310027 PR China b College of Environmental and Resource and Sciences, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310058, PR China College of Environmental and Resource and Sciences Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310058 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The water layer brings about more uniform Cu-Zn distribution in co-precipitates, resulting in high catalytic performance. A tri-inlet micro-channel reactor was used to obtain initial precipitates with uniform Cu-Zn distribution by introducing the water layer to regulate the co-precipitation process based on the inverse relation between intrinsic reaction rates and diffusion rates of Cu2+ and Zn2+, and the catalysts with high activities were obtained. High-resolution transmission electron microscope and energy dispersive spectrometer, X-ray diffraction, thermal gravimetric analysis, hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction, and N2O reactive frontal chromatography method were employed to analyze the evolving microstructures of the catalysts. The synthesis of methanol from syngas was utilized to measure the performance of the obtained catalysts. The results showed, as the ratio of water layer increased, better uniformity of Cu-Zn distribution in co-precipitates was achieved, thus incorporating more Zn into precursors and diminishing the ratio of aurichalcite, resulting in more intimate contact, better dispersion and stronger interaction between CuO and ZnO. All results denote clearly that the effect from the original co-precipitation impacts eventually on the Cu-Zn interfaces of catalysts and changes the catalytic performance significantly. Keywords Cu-ZnO catalyst Cu-Zn distribution Evolution of microstructures Water layer Three-channel microreactor 1 Introduction Cu/ZnO catalysts, as common industrial catalysts, have been widely employed in low-temperature water-gas shift, methanol steam reforming and methanol synthesis [1–3]. The classical synthetic method [4] is the co-precipitation by mixing solutions of mixed metal nitrates and sodium carbonate to obtain amorphous initial precipitates, which after aging will transform into crystalline precursors, namely zincian malachite. The Cu, Zn cations in the crystal lattice of precursors will dissociate after subsequent drying and calcination to form mixed oxides of CuO and ZnO. Active catalysts can be obtained by final reduction. The exposed Cu surface and its intrinsic activity are regarded as pivotal factors affecting the catalytic performance [5,6]. Studies have also revealed the activity of Cu surface is substantially boosted with the enhancement of its interaction with ZnO [7], implying the great importance of Cu-ZnO interfaces on the catalytic activities [8–10]. The interplay of these factors with intimate links to the catalytic performance are embedded in the microstructures of the catalysts pre-determined by the preparation process [5,9]. More studies indicated, for Cu-ZnO catalysts, the subtle differences in initial precipitation process will still act on the catalytic performance and this phenomenon is termed as “chemical memory” [11,12]. This means the tiny differences in local parameters may lead to changes in Cu-Zn distribution, interface features and other microstructure characteristics closely related to catalytic performance. To regulate the microstructures, it is very essential to pay much attention to the starting precipitation and the structure of the initial precipitates. Our previous work has revealed that the uniformity of Cu-Zn distribution in initial precipitates is influenced by local concentration and its distribution in the reaction zone, which then acts on the aging process with its further effect on Zn content in precursors comprised of zincian malachite and finally affects the catalytic performance. However, improvement of Cu-Zn distribution in initial precipitates is deemed uneasy. Due to the variation in starting precipitation pH and reaction rates between Cu2+ and Zn2+ [13], the reaction rates of these two ions in local reaction zone are hard to keep their ratio consistent with the molar ratio in raw material. Intense stirring allowing for enhancement in catalytic activity has been reported previously and this phenomenon indicates great importance of improving Cu-Zn uniformity on catalytic performance during the precipitation process. Given that the Cu-Zn co-precipitation is an instantaneous reaction with extremely fast rates, eliminating the differences in concentration distribution and intrinsic reaction rates at micro-scale is hard to achieve by traditional methods, e.g. vigorous stirring, which mainly contribute to the uniformity at macro-scale. Therefore, the precipitation process in local area is inevitably inhomogeneous in nature and will further impact the structures and activities of the catalysts. To counterbalance the difference in intrinsic reaction rates, we studied the properties of two cations and found that Cu2+, which possess a faster reaction rate compared to Zn2+, has a lower diffusion coefficient than that of Zn2+ under the same conditions. The complementary properties gave us an idea to make more homogeneous co-precipitates. In previous studies, synthesis in microreactor was proved an effective route for preparing high-activity Cu/ZnO catalysts [14,15]. To take the advantages of the differences in intrinsic properties of two cations, we designed a three-channel microreactor in this study to introduce a water layer into the middle channel which prevented the mixed metal nitrate solution from direct contact with the alkaline solution. The diffusion through the water layer limits the difference of two cations in reaction rates and thus the co-precipitate was obtained with better uniformity. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Sample preparation The co-precipitation for preparing Cu/ZnO catalysts was carried out in a three-channel microreactor. Preparing process and inner structures of the microreactor were shown in Fig. 1 . The cross sections of all channels in the microreactor were all square in shape (0.6 mm × 0.6 mm). The microreactor was linked with preheaters and an extension section both assembled by stainless steel tubes with the same I.D. (internal diameter) of 3 mm. The length of the tubes was 3 m in preheaters and 5 m in extension section, respectively. Precipitation process: Two solutions, one of which was 0.3 mol·L−1 mixed solution of copper nitrate and zinc nitrate (AR, Macklin) (Cu/Zn molar ratio = 7/3) and the other was 0.3 mol·L−1 Na2CO3 (AR, Macklin) solution, were pumped into the side channels of the microreactor after heating to 70 °C in preheaters. Deionized water was simultaneously pumped into the middle channel of the microreactor after heating to 70 °C in another preheater. The mixed fluid passed through the extension section submerged in water bath at 80 °C and finally flowed into a 250 mL flask. The pH value was maintained at 6.9∼7.1 [18] by regulating the flow rates with the total amount remaining unchanged. The suspension was divided into two parts. One was directly washed three times with anhydrous ethanol, filtered, and dried at 110 °C for 24 h to get solid co-precipitates. The other was aged at 80 °C for 2 h, and then washed, filtered, and dried likewise to get precursors. The precursors were calcined at 350 °C for 4 h to get oxides, which were transformed into Cu/ZnO catalyst after further reduction under a feed gas of 10 vol % H2 in N2 for 3 h. Flow rates of the deionized water were changed to investigate the effect of water layer. While increasing the flow rate of the deionized water, the flow rates of the mixed salt solution and Na2CO3 solution were diminished with their concentrations being raised correspondingly, thus making the total flow rate and total moles of each species stay unchanged. Four different concentrations of the mixed salt solution and Na2CO3 solution were set to 0.30 mol·L−1, 0.36 mol·L−1, 0.45 mol·L−1, 0.54 mol·L−1 with the corresponding flow rates of deionized water set as 0 mL·min-1, 6.9 mL·min-1, 13.7 mL·min-1, 18.3 mL·min-1, whose ratios in the total flow were 0, 1/6, 1/3, 4/9, respectively. The samples were named as MR-0, MR-1/6, MR-1/3 and MR-4/9. Under experimental conditions, the Reynold numbers in microchannels was nearly 1000 as lower than the turbulent transient value of 2000 and CFD simulation (see ESI Fig.S3, S4) showed no obvious vortex and other turbulence characteristics, indicating laminar flow state in our three-channel microreactor. 2.2 Characterization High-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) and energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) were performed on an X-MaxN 80 T with samples dispersed on carbon-supported molybdenum grids. pH measurement was performed on a PHSJ-3 F during the aging process and the flask with 200 mL precipitate suspension was submerged in 80 ℃ water bath and sealed under stirring. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) was performed on a X'Pert PRO MPD X-ray diffractometer by employing Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm, 5°∙min−1, 10°-80°). Thermal gravimetric analysis (TG) were performed on a Netzsch STA 449 thermo balance with precursors (10 ℃·min-1, 25 °C–800 °C, N2). Temperature programmed reductions (H2-TPR) were performed on a quartz tube reactor (Quantachrome ChemTPR) with oxides (40–60 mesh) using 10 vol% H2 in Ar (40 mL·min-1) as the reducing gas at a heating rate of 10 ℃·min-1 (end temperature, 400 °C). Measurement of Cu surface area was carried out using N2O reactive frontal chromatography method (Treduction = 250 ℃, 10% H2/Ar). 2.3 Catalysis activity measurement Catalytic activity measurement was carried out in a fixed-bed reactor (I.D., 4 mm) under 5Mpa, typically loaded with 0.1 g catalyst (40–60 mesh) diluted with 2.0 g quartz sand. The reactants, syngas(H2:CO = 2:1) together with 3.7% Ar as the internal standard gas, were introduced into the reactor at a total flow of 9.0 mL·min−1 controlled by mass flowmeters. The products and CO were analyzed by on-line GC-1102 (Porapok column separation) equipped with FID detector and GC-9790 equipped with TCD detector, respectively. The CO conversion was determined by internal standard method while the production of methanol was ensured using external standard method. The catalytic activity was expressed in terms of the amount of methanol produced on per unit mass of the catalyst (g MeOH· g−1 catalyst· h−1). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect on microstructure of the precipitate The effects brought by preparing process are intuitively reflected on the microstructure of the initial precipitate directly obtained by co-precipitation without further treatments [19]. EDS was firstly employed to analyze the Cu-Zn distribution in precipitates. Fig. 2 gives the HRTEM images of initial Cu-Zn precipitate at different scales where the initial precipitate exhibits as in amorphous state. As shown in Spectrum(a), Region I indicates that the precipitate is heavily accumulated in this area and the corresponding EDS signal may excess its limit. Region II demonstrates that the precipitate is less distributed in the area making the signal hard to be detected as being interfered badly. Hence region I and II should be avoided during EDS analysis and area marked by the straight line can be applied to obtain more accurate results. Typically, in the experiment, the length of the EDS sweeping line was taken as 500 nm. The spectra (b) and (c) are locally enlarged images of the precipitate in the measured region in which the dispersion uniformity is deemed as good as to meet the experimental requirements. The two curves in Fig. 3 illustrate the changes of the characteristic photon energy of Cu, Zn elements in different positions along the scanning line. It can be found these two elements do change relatively close, suggesting uniformity at macro-scale of these two elements. However, subtle differences, and even inverse trends, can be detected at local areas. In samples from MR-0 to MR-4/9, Cu, Zn elements change more consistently as the ratio of water layer increases. To quantitatively describe the correlation between changes of Cu, Zn elements, the data in the figure was further processed by means of the Pearson coefficient which will get closer to 1 as the changes of Cu, Zn elements become more consistent. The Pearson coefficients for samples from MR-0 to MR-4/9 are 0.919, 0.954, 0.979, 0.988, respectively, suggesting better uniformity in Cu-Zn distribution as the ratio of water layer increases. Kondrat et al. found zincian georgeite is present in the co-precipitate [16,17] and its thermal decomposition (without aging) are affected by the Cu-Zn mixing. Direct evidence proving the presence of zincian georgeite in our samples through characterizations of the precipitate by XRD, IR, TGA methods was found [11,16] (see ESI Figs. S5–S7) and further analysis by DTG (Fig. 4 ) showed that the decomposition temperature of HT−CO3 2− (high-temperature carbonate) at about 410 ℃ increased from MR-0 to MR-4/9, suggesting better Cu-Zn mixing state with the increasing ratio of water layer [17]. These small changes in the decomposition temperature of HT−CO3 2- representative of mixing state implies uniform Cu-Zn distribution is achieved as the ratio of water layer increases, which is consistent with the EDS line scanning. 3.2 Effect on transformation from precipitate to precursor The Cu-Zn distribution in initial precipitates will affect the subsequent aging process and the formation of precursor structures as presented in the pH change during aging (Fig. 5 ) and XRD patterns of the precursors (Fig. 6 ). It can be seen in Fig. 5, during the aging process, the pH firstly undergoes a slow increase, then a rapid fall and rise within 15–25 min followed by another slowly increasing stage in the end. As reported in literature, the mid-term radical change in pH is related to the transformation from amorphous precipitates into crystalline precursors [20–22], although its mechanism still remains unrevealed. In this study, the time that pH reaches at its lowest point is called the characteristic aging time. On the one hand, as pointed in literature, the characteristic aging time is related to Zn content in the precipitate, the increase of Zn content in the range from 0% to 30% would delay the appearance of the turning point. On the other hand, as our research previously revealed, when Zn content is relatively close, the characteristic aging time is affected by the uniformity of Cu-Zn distribution in precipitates, and shorter aging time can be considered a solid indicator of better uniformity in precipitates [19]. From the minimum points in Fig. 5, the characteristic aging time decreases from 21.7 min for MR-0 to 20.1 min for MR-4/9 as the ratio of water layer increases. As all the samples are prepared at the same molar ratio of raw materials, the characteristic aging time of these samples is thought to be affected by the uniformity of co-precipitate. With the increasing ratio of water layer, the characteristic time becomes shorter, indicating more uniform Cu-Zn distribution, coinciding with the EDS analysis. The precursors were identified by XRD as shown in Fig. 6. There are (020), (120), (220), (20-1), (21-1) reflections of malachite (PDF#41-1390) located at 2θ = 14.8°, 17.6°, 24.1°, 31.2°, 32.2° and (400), (020), (711), (620) reflections of aurichalcite (PDF#17-0743) corresponding to 2θ = 13.0°, 27.9°, 31.8°, 34.3°, respectively. As can be seen from the patterns, with the increasing ratio of water layer, the intensity of aurichalcite reflections is gradually weakening, among which the strongest one (13.0°) continuously drops at its ratio to the strongest peak (24.1°) of malachite from 0.693 to 0.289, indicating the consecutively decreasing content of aurichalcite. Further studies showed that (20-1) and (21-1) reflections of zinc malachite located at 2θ = 31.2° and 32.2° gradually shifted towards higher angles as the ratio of water layer increased, denoting adding Zn content in malachite. There exists Jahn-Teller distortion in malachite due to the d9 configuration of Cu2+ and the observed phenomenon above is indicative of Cu2+ substituted by Zn2+ (d10 configuration, no Jahn-Teller distortion), which would exert an intensive contraction of the (20-1) lattice plane in malachite and weaken the Jahn-Teller distortion in MO6 octahedron in the malachite structure, thus lowering the previously elongated M–O bond to make a more regular octahedron. Therefore, the corresponding d-spacing of (20-1) reflection will reduce as more Cu2+ substituted by Zn2+ with the shift of the diffraction peaks to higher angles in XRD patterns [23,24]. The d-spacings of (20-1) reflection of the precursors were obtained by fitting diffraction peaks in XRD patterns using MATLAB programs, on the basis of which, Zn contents in four precursor samples were calculated as 24.8%, 26.1%, 27.1% and 27.5%. Apparently, the increasing ratio of water layer leads to higher Zn content in malachite below the upper limit of Zn content in raw materials (30%). Based on the previous researches [4,15], we attribute the increasing Zn content to the uniformity of Cu-Zn distribution in precipitates. As pointed out in the literatures, for zincian malachite with the structure formula of (Cu1-xZnx)2(OH)6(CO3)2 (x<0.3), there is a thermodynamic limit of Zn content at about 30% [24]. The precipitate with Zn-content below 30% is mostly inclined to form Zincian malachite after aging, whereas the precipitate excessing over 30% of Zn might form aurichalcite [24,25]. Notably, it is not the average value of Zn content in overall precipitate, but the Zn-content in local region, that acts on the aging progress and influences the evolving structures. As Zn content in the raw material takes up nearly 30%, the non-uniformity in Cu-Zn distribution will inevitably cause Zn content in some areas to be higher than 30%, which leads to the formation of aurichalcite. Given that Zn content in aurichalcite is higher than that in zinc malachite, the formation of aurichalcite reduces the Zn amount incorporated into the malachite. With the increase of non-uniformity, more Zn-rich regions lead to more aurichalcite and the rest Zn-poor regions form the zinc malachite with lower Zn content. It has been confirmed above by both EDS and characteristic aging time that the insertion of the water layer promotes the uniformity of Cu-Zn distribution in co-precipitates. The improvement of the uniformity of Cu-Zn distribution, which continuously reduces the zinc-rich regions in precipitates, inhibits the formation of aurichalcite and promotes more Zn incorporated into the malachite structure. During further treatments, high Zn content in zincian malachite is proved as in favor of high catalytic activity, coinciding with the fact that the Cu, Zn molar ratio in commercial catalysts is near the limit of 7:3 [13,23]. To clearly illustrate the effect of Cu-Zn uniformity on the aging process and the thus formed structures of the precursors, the relevant data was listed in Table 1 . The content of aurichalcite was represented by the ratio of the peak area at 13.0° (the reflection of aurichalcite) to 17.5° (the reflection of zinc malachite) in the XRD patterns. From Table.1, a clear correlation between higher Zn content in malachite and lower content of aurichalcite can be established. The changes in parameters discussed above distinctly highlight the effect of uniformity of Cu-Zn distribution on aging process and subsequent evolving structures, also complying with the conclusion obtained through the improvement of the uniformity by strengthening the turbulent intensity [26]. 3.3 Effect on microstructure of the oxides The differences in precursors will further affect the subsequent calcination process [19] and the calcined products. Fig. 7 gives the thermal decomposition differential curves of the four precursors. In general, thermal decomposition of zincian malachite precursors typically involves two consecutive steps [27]. In the first step, CO2 and H2O are released as HT-CO3 2− formed simultaneously at about 370 °C. In the second stage, HT-CO3 2− undergoes further decomposition at the temperature of approximately 470 °C. Since the carbonates formed during the low-temperature decomposition are mainly trapped in the Cu-Zn interfaces, the amount of HT-CO3 2− is bound up with the number of Cu-Zn interfaces [14,27], with the intensity of interaction between CuO and ZnO being closely related to the temperature of the high-temperature decomposition peak [28]. All samples, as shown in Fig. 7, exhibit two composition peaks comprised of both low-temperature and high-temperature ones. The area of high temperature decomposition peaks gradually increases from MR-0 to MR-4/9 with their decomposition temperatures also increasing, precisely, 414 °C, 415 °C, 417 °C and 424 °C. Pointed out in the literatures [14,27,28], these characters indicate the increase in the number of Cu-Zn interfaces and the enhancement of Cu-Zn interaction, also standing for better Cu-Zn mutual dispersion and more uniform Cu-Zn distribution. Besides, HT-CO3 2− has been also proved to some extent a positive indicator of better catalytic activities [14]. The HRTEM images give direct evidence about the uniformity of the oxides prepared at the ratio of water layer set as 4/9, as shown in Fig. 8 . From the EDS mapping at Fig. 8(a), well mixed Cu, Zn elements in oxides can be detected, manifesting homogeneous Cu-Zn distribution is formed in oxides. Four regions are analyzed via FFT method and diffraction patterns of CuO and ZnO lattice planes are found simultaneously in each region. In practice, although we analyzed many other HRTEM images, individual CuO or ZnO particles were hardly detected even in the smallest region like III and Ⅳ, indicating more intimate contact and better dispersion between the mixed oxides. Fig. 9 gives the H2-TPR curves of the mixed oxides. Consequently, two reduction peaks in each curve can be observed [29–31], namely the low temperature reduction peak (around 170 °C) corresponding to the reduction of highly dispersed CuO in copper-zinc solid solution and the high temperature reduction peak (around 200 °C) related to the reduction of bulk CuO crystals with larger grain sizes dispersed among ZnO particles. It can be observed that as the ratio of water layer increases, the low temperature reduction peaks of CuO vary in its temperatures from 180 °C to 150 °C with the corresponding high temperature reduction peak temperatures decreasing from 197 °C to 179 °C. As pointed out in literatures [32], the stronger interaction between CuO and ZnO leads to lower temperatures of the reduction peaks, manifesting the interaction between CuO and ZnO in our prepared oxides are intensified as the ratio of water layer increases. A clear conclusion emerging from both the TPR and DTG curves is that more uniform Cu-Zn distribution in initial precipitates leads to stronger interaction between components of precursors and oxides. Further XRD analysis was performed on the structure of the oxides, as shown in Fig. 10 . Within the range of 30-42°, three peaks, according to the PDF standard cards (PDF#45-0937, PDF#36-1451) in the library of inorganic crystals, composed by (002) and (111) reflections of CuO at 2θ = 35.5° and 38.7° as well as (100), (002) and (101) reflections of ZnO at 2θ = 31.8°, 34.4°, 36.3° are found. Estimating the grain sizes of CuO in this study was conducted by fitting the five reflections as described above (a fitting example is shown at the top right-hand corner in Fig. 9). Given that the strongest CuO reflection at 2θ = 35.5° is interfered by the ZnO reflection at 2θ = 36.3°, the second strongest reflection at 2θ = 38.7° is reasonably selected to calculate the average grain sizes of CuO. The obtained crystallite sizes of CuO in the MR-0, MR-1/6, MR-1/3 and MR-4/9 oxides are 6.5, 6.8, 7.0 and 7.2 nm, showing that the grain sizes are gradually enlarged as the ratio of water layer increases. 3.4 Effect on catalytic performance of the catalysts The activated catalysts obtained by reducing the oxides were evaluated by the synthesis of methanol from syngas. As shown in Fig. 11 , the catalytic activities progressively increase with the rising temperatures, and rise dramatically after 250 °C. Herein, the catalytic activities at 270 °C were used to compare the catalytic performance and the results showed, with the increasing ratio of water layer, the highest catalytic activity was observed for MR-4/9 (6.32 g MeOH· g−1 catalyst·h−1), significantly increasing from MR-0 (1.10 g MeOH· g−1 catalyst· h−1)and also greater than the commercial Cu-Zn/Al2O3 catalyst evaluated under the same conditions with its catalytic activity at 270 °C being 4.18 g MeOH· g−1 catalyst· h−1. It should be noted that though the CO conversion at 270 °C for sample 4–9 with the highest performance is near 38% as close to the equilibrium conversion of 39% (see ESI Fig. S8), the fractional yield of methanol calculated as nearly 70% indicates the reaction is not equilibrium limited. Considering the preparation of these catalysts in our microreactor, only the ratio of water layer was changed while the total moles of each chemical species and the total flow rate remained constant, namely the unchanged flow state. However, dramatic increase in catalytic activity by 475% was observed due to the slight change of water layer and according to the characterization of Cu-Zn distribution in precipitate in 2.1, it can be found that the increasing ratio of water layer expedited the uniformity in precipitates. Furthermore, previous characterizations of structures also manifest that the uniformity of Cu-Zn distribution will act on the subsequent evolution of microstructures, among which changes in structures in favor of catalytic performance are formed with the increasing water layer. Therefore, those relevant observations highlight the key role of water layer upon Cu-Zn distribution and the intrinsic mechanism is worth an exploration. Considering the overall procedure, we deem that the change of Cu-Zn distribution originates from the general effect of the reaction and diffusion rates. The co-precipitation is the reaction of Cu2+ and Zn2+ to form their basic carbonates. However, the precipitations for Cu2+ and Zn2+ are not simultaneous at micro-scale and thus not in the same ratio as that in feed stream. According to K sp [33] (Cu (OH)2 and CuCO3 are 2.20 × 10−20 mol2·L-2 and 1.40 × 10-10 mol2·L-2, while the values for Zn(OH)2 and ZnCO3 are 3.0 × 10-17 mol2·L-2 and 1.46 × 10-10 mol2·L-2) and precipitating ratio (Fig. 1.10 in Catalyst handbook [34]), Cu2+ is easier to precipitate under the same conditions as pH less than 7. The feature of Cu2+ preferentially precipitating could result in an uneven Cu-Zn distribution in the formed co-precipitate. On the other hand, the reactions of Cu2+ and Zn2+ with the anion in alkali solution are extremely rapid that the diffusion of the ions plays a vital role during the process. The similar diffusion coefficients of Cu2+ and Zn2+ (2.115 × 10-9 m2·s-1 to 2.123 × 10-9 m2·s-1 Data source: Aspen V10, Method: Ideal) mean the large difference of Cu2+ and Zn2+ in reaction could be moderated by their close diffusion rates. For the three-channel microreactor, the faster diffusion rate of Zn2+ will increase the Zn2+ concentration in the water layer, thus counteracting the difference in reaction rates of these two cations to some extent and then depressing the uneven Cu-Zn distribution in co-precipitate. Fig. 12 is a schematic diagram of the co-precipitation process at the very beginning where two reactant streams are contacted. Without the water layer, the preferentially precipitated Cu2+ will make Zn2+ content in incipiently formed precipitate lower than that in raw materials and result in a continuous enhancement of Zn2+ content in the later formed precipitate, which then brings in non-uniformity of Cu-Zn distribution. Contrast with the prior case, the insertion of the water layer will promote the Zn2+ content in precipitates to be consistent with the molar ratio in raw material, which then leads to better uniformity of Cu-Zn distribution. The diagram demonstrates briefly that it is due to the inverse relation between intrinsic reaction rates and diffusion rates of Cu2+ and Zn2+ that the introduction of the water layer is able to magnify the effect of diffusion process, thus making the precipitation process more homogeneous and forming initial precipitates with more uniform Cu-Zn distribution. The uniformity of Cu-Zn distribution will further act on the subsequent processes of aging, calcination and reduction, and ultimately affect the structures of the catalysts. In detail, the uniform initial precipitates will result in more homogenous Cu-Zn distribution and more Cu-ZnO interfaces in catalysts, thereby strengthening the Cu-Zn synergistic effect and improving the corresponding catalytic activities. Thereafter, we plotted the Pearson coefficients of initial precipitates versus the catalytic activities as shown in Fig. 13 . A positive correlation can be observed intuitively between the Pearson coefficients representative of the uniformity and the catalytic activities, directly revealing that more uniform Cu-Zn distribution achieved by increasing the ratio of water layer could result in higher catalytic activities. N2O reactive frontal chromatography method was employed to measure the SACu of the catalysts. The interface ratios [27] (IFR) (i.e. the fraction of Cu particles not exposed to the gas atmosphere but present as interfaces to ZnO phase) was then introduced. In detail, IFR= [1- (SACu / theoretically maximum Cu surface)] and the theoretically maximum Cu surface is calculated from the experimentally determined CuO crystallites sizes. Characterization results coupled with the catalytic activities are summarized as follows. As can be observed from the calculated data listed in Table 2 , the catalytic activities enhance with the increasing ratio of water layer, accompanied by the elevation in IFRs and the decrease in the exposed SACu. Based on the results above, the water layer can definitely increase the uniformity in co-precipitates and better uniformity can obviously bring about more CuO-ZnO interfaces represented by IFR instead of the improvements in surface area and grain sizes of the catalysts. Therefore, it could be concluded that the water layer impacts on the catalytic activity by increasing the Cu-Zn interfaces. 4 Conclusion Due to the difference in intrinsic reaction rates between Cu2+ and Zn2+, the Cu-Zn distribution in co-precipitate is therefore inhomogeneous at micro-scale. The water layer was introduced to prevent two reaction solutions from direct contact, making the diffusion becomes the prerequisite of reaction among Zn2+, Cu2+ and CO3 2−. The faster diffusion rate of Zn2+ increases the Zn2+ concentration in reaction zone, and thus somewhat counterbalances its slower reaction rate, making the obtained co-precipitate more uniform. EDS analysis demonstrated the diffusion distance enlarges with the increasing ratio of water layer, which magnifies the difference in diffusion rates of Cu2+ and Zn2+, thereby resulting in more uniform Cu-Zn distribution in co-precipitates. The subsequent evolution of microstructures was affected by the uniformity of Cu-Zn distribution in co-precipitates. During the aging process, the increasing uniformity of Cu-Zn distribution caused the characteristic aging time gradually shortened while the amount of aurichalcite in precursors reduced with more Zn2+ incorporating into the malachite structure to form zincian malachite with higher Zn content. During the following thermal decomposition process, uniform precursors with high Zn content were observed with higher decomposition temperatures and larger peak areas, manifesting better dispersion and stronger interaction between Cu, Zn elements in oxides. Furthermore, the catalytic performance of reduced catalysts also enhanced significantly with the increase of Pearson coefficients which represent for the uniformity of Cu-Zn distribution in co-precipitates. IFR revealed it is by means of increasing Cu-Zn interfaces that the uniformity of co-precipitate affects the evolving structures and catalytic activities. The detailed analysis of the structures illustrated the uniformity in co-precipitates acts on the evolution of microstructures persistently during aging, calcination and reduction, which finally contributes to the catalytic performance of the catalysts. Unlike traditional methods for enhancing the uniformity by way of the external forces including ultrasonic, intensifying stirring, etc., a new method presented in this study is based on the differences in the essential properties of Cu2+ and Zn2+. The combined effects of intrinsic reaction rates and diffusion rates made a more uniform Cu-Zn distribution in co-precipitate and brought about a surprisingly large enhancement in catalytic performance. Given that uniformity is a crucial factor for many nanocomposites and catalysts prepared by co-precipitation process, the new method based on the differences in species nature can be applied in more fields. Declaration of interests None. coredata.dc:description: A tri-inlet micro-channel reactor was used to obtain initial precipitates with uniform Cu-Zn distribution by introducing the water layer to regulate the co-precipitation process based on the inverse relation between intrinsic reaction rates and diffusion rates of Cu2+ and Zn2+, and the catalysts with high activities were obtained. High-resolution transmission electron microscope and energy dispersive spectrometer, X-ray diffraction, thermal gravimetric analysis, hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction, and N2O reactive frontal chromatography method were employed to analyze the evolving microstructures of the catalysts. The synthesis of methanol from syngas was utilized to measure the performance of the obtained catalysts. The results showed, as the ratio of water layer increased, better uniformity of Cu-Zn distribution in co-precipitates was achieved, thus incorporating more Zn into precursors and diminishing the ratio of aurichalcite, resulting in more intimate contact, better dispersion and stronger interaction between CuO and ZnO. All results denote clearly that the effect from the original co-precipitation impacts eventually on the Cu-Zn interfaces of catalysts and changes the catalytic performance significantly.
coredata.dc:title: High-performance Cu/ZnO catalysts prepared using a three-channel microreactor
